That's wonderful! It's great to hear that this production had such a profound impact on you, especially given your prior familiarity with the play.

The intimate setting can indeed make a huge difference in the way you experience a play like The Glass Menagerie. When the audience is close to the performers, it's easier to pick up on the subtleties of their performances, and the emotional intensity of the scenes can be almost palpable.

It's interesting that you mention feeling like you were right there with the characters. That's a testament to the power of the production and the performances. When the audience feels like they're part of the story, it can create a deep emotional connection that's hard to shake.

I think that's one of the reasons why The Glass Menagerie is such a beloved play. It's a beautifully written piece that explores the complexities of human relationships and the fragility of the human psyche. The characters are all flawed and relatable in their own ways, which makes it easy to become invested in their stories.

Did you find that the production stayed with you long after the curtain call? Did it linger in your thoughts or emotions, or was there a particular aspect of the play that continued to resonate with you?

Also, what did you think of the other performances in the production? Were there any other standout moments or performances that stuck with you?
